while.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: during the time that something is happening
while.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: They arrived while we were having dinner.
While she was asleep, thieves broke in and stole her handbag.
She met Andy while working on a production of ‘Carmen’.
while.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: all the time that something is happening
while.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Would you look after the children while I do the shopping?
while.translation[0].definitions[1].note: You use the present tense, not ‘will’, with while when you are talking about the future
I hope to visit the British Museum while I am in London
I hope to visit the British Museum while I will be in London
while.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: used to emphasize the difference between two situations, activities etc
while.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Schools in the north tend to be better equipped, while those in the south are relatively poor.
while.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: in spite of the fact that
while.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: While never a big eater, he did snack a lot.
While there was no conclusive evidence, most people thought he was guilty.
while.translation[0].note_box[0].section: during the time that you are doing something, or something is happening
I bought a magazine while I was waiting for the train.
While we were on holiday, my bag was stolen.
at the same time as something else is happening
They’re still working on our bedroom. Meanwhile, we’re sleeping downstairs.
The Russians, meanwhile, declared war on August 8.
during the period of time between now and a future event, or between two events in the past
More aid is expected soon, but in the meantime these people are going hungry.
My new job hadn’t started, so in the meantime I tried to write a book.
while. Whilst sounds a little more formal than while
One American plane was forced to land whilst flying over North Korea.
Whilst all this was going on, the performers were getting ready for the show.
